text: Family Member: You’re talking about placebo? Doctor: Yeah. So there is a two out of three chance that you will have a chance to get that medication. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: If, if I need that medication, I could though? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There is some unknowns, quite a bit of unknowns, in terms of what side effects to expect. There is the possibility of – obviously we’ll be monitoring your kidney function, liver function, all of that pretty closely and be monitoring you for any side effects. I mean you tell me more than what anybody knows about this medication sometimes. But uh for the most part it seems to have been okay tolerated in the very, very preliminary, very few patients that have been on it. Patient: What about the diabetes? How does that fit in to this discussion? Doctor: We will have to see if it affects sugars and then accordingly adjust your medications for the diabetes. But right now I don’t know for sure that it does or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be monitoring glucose every time anyway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. Patient: Just with… Family Member: With what? Doctor: They’re PKs as you get blood draws every few hours. So you have to sit there though for a good all day long basically. Patient: I have to be like in the clinic or hospital? Doctor: Yeah. But this will have to be…

text: Family Member: You went out on the deck. Patient: No. I’m talking about walking. I’m not talking about that now. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Right. I just wanted to clarify. Patient: But I went out to, uh, to see how, how to walk because sometimes it was difficult walking especially with this leg here. And, uh, I don’t, I don’t know, I had a whole lot of pep in my step- Doctor: Okay. Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night.

text: Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: But there is a newer hormonal therapy that also we can consider for you. Now that is sort of an earlier phase trial, so it’s a phase one trial. Okay. But the advantage is that we’ve already been through a number of the dosing levels. So typically a phase one trial is where you’re getting something very new that’s worked amazingly well in the lab that now you’re testing in people. So the first few dose levels really are trying to see what kind of side effects and what dose level really has… Patient: Sure. Doctor: But you’ll have some long days and things like that, you would have the hotel and mileage covered you know same as this study for that matter. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (clears throat) Doctor: So those things would be covered, but it is a matter of whether you’re willing to come back and forth. Patient: Well I guess... Family Member: How long would we have to do that for that just out of curiosity? Doctor: It’s a, I’ll give you the exact… Doctor: Yeah but it’s more for the monitoring and because it’s a phase one trial it’s a little bit more closer monitoring. At least the first few weeks. After that it goes down to once a month once we sort of get the comfort level that you’re tolerating it okay, we know all the PKs and the blood level things are done, then it becomes much easier schedule. Family Member: What are the, how often are you talking about? A couple times a week or? Doctor: Well the first few weeks it will be about once a week or so or once every couple of weeks after a little while. And then after the first couple of months it goes to like I said once every four weeks.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It would be very different if the spot was in the bone. Bone metastasis takes a very long time to disappear. Sometimes you know a small one can take up to a year to disappear. So oftentimes when a cancer is involved, when they start the hormone therapy about three months later, a week later, two weeks later you talk to the radiation oncologist and by the time he starts the radiation planning which might be six to eight weeks later, the spot is still where he can see it, he can zap it and target that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And with a lymph node, uh if we start the hormone therapy even like a couple of weeks before that thing’s going to disappear; he won’t know what he’s targeting. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So all I’m saying is in theory that- Family Member: Right, Okay. Doctor: -combination that you just outlined kind of again makes sense, but I view it as to me the main purpose of doing the radio therapy would not be necessarily that you will have some sort of combined benefit in conjunction with the hormone therapy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It would be for the purpose of delaying the hormones that much longer. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: So I kind of view that as the primary motivation for doing that. But to me the primary motivation for radiation would be we’re doing something rather than just continue to observe you.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
